page.title: 16The Snake Road
page.content: The{Snake Road (A57)}goes from{ {Glossop}to{Sheffield.}It was built in{ {1821,}one of the last turnpike roads in Britain. The original charges were{ {two and a half pence}for horses and carriages. Clergy, postmen and soldiers went free. The highest point is{1,680 feet} above sea level, and in winter the road is sometimes closed by snowdrifts. There are special road open/closed signs along the road from Manchester. The road crosses wild and fine scenary. The name reflects the winding nature of the road but could also come from the{snake}on the{Cavendish}coat of arms once found on the{Snake Inn.} In{summer}there is a special bus service over this route on{Sundays.} It is mainly used by tourists and walkers.
